The Auckland Folk Festival is New Zealand's largest folk music and dance festival. Come and celebrate the 53rd annual festival at the Kumeū Showgrounds on Auckland Anniversary Weekend. View times One of the oldest folk festivals in the Southern Hemisphere brings multiple stages of exceptional artists from here at home in Aotearoa and from around the globe. We’ll be spoiled for choice as some of the best traditional and contemporary folk musicians and folk dancers come together to showcase our amazing genre. Whatever your taste in folk music there will be something for you to savour. If you want to participate in one of the black board concerts or workshops, so much the better. If you’d rather dance the night away, then there are venues for you. And in the wee small hours don’t forget to wander round and catch some of the magic jam sessions and sing-alongs. Food trucks will be cooking up a storm all weekend, offering up a wide range of options, along with something to quench your thirst. Our Kids Stage and Zone is growing year by year. To absorb the friendly family vibe, try camping for the weekend. Immerse yourself in the centre of things, or choose a quiet camping area. And if you are not a natural camper, Kumeū is close enough to Auckland to come out each day. Children under 10 are free. The Festival will kick off on the Friday evening at 7pm, and music will run until late on Sunday night. Keep up to date with announcements and information by following on Facebook, Instagram or joining our mailing list. Te wāhi He tīwhiri mō te rohe Get your fix of food, crafts and live music at the Kumeū Market, held the third Sunday of the month almost all year round (closed over some summer months). Te huarahi ki reira Kumeū Showgrounds is a 20-minute drive from the city, with plenty of parking available.

description: celebrates and amplifies the plural artistic voices of the United States. Opening with an iconic 1948 drip painting by Jackson Pollock and closing with a poignant sculptural assemblage by the Alabama-based artist Thornton Dial, this landmark presentation of 52 compelling works from the world-renowned Virginia Museum of Fine Arts offers a comprehensive overview of the principal themes and styles shaping American art since 1945. A major cultural event for Aotearoa New Zealand, this special exhibition includes high-quality examples of Abstract Expressionism, Pop and Minimalism along with richly textured paintings by Pattern and Decoration artists, hyper-detailed canvases by 1970s Photorealists, and contemporary figurative pieces that explore questions of identity, power and representation. Showcasing 28 works by women and African American and Indigenous artists, places well-known names in conversation with figures from diverse backgrounds to provide a more inclusive account of recent American art. Artists featured in this broad and nuanced survey include Benny Andrews, Rosalyn Drexler, Elaine de Kooning, Willem de Kooning, Helen Frankenthaler, Sam Gilliam, Philip Guston, Barkley L. Hendricks, Norman Lewis, Roy Lichtenstein, Virgil Ortiz, Howardena Pindell, Martin Puryear, Jaune Quick-to-See Smith, Mark Rothko, Kiki Smith, Clyfford Still, Cy Twombly, Andy Warhol and Jack Whitten. is organised by the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts in Richmond, Virginia. It is curated by Alexis Assam, Regina A. Perrry Assistant Curator of Modern and Contemporary Art, and Dr. Sarah G. Powers, Exhibition Curator. Kenneth Brummel, Curator of International Art, is the co-ordinating curator at Auckland Art Gallery Toi o Tāmaki. The exhibition is presented in association with Te Ahurei Toi o Tāmaki Auckland Arts Festival 2026, and proudly supported by Auckland Art Gallery Foundation, Omnigraphics, Rova and Stuff. : Roy Lichtenstein, ‘Gullscape’ (installation view) (detail), 1964, Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, Gift of Sydney and Frances Lewis, 85.418 © Estate of Roy Lichtenstein/Copyright Agency, 2025. Members have priority but please note that there might be a wait time when the exhibition is at capacity. Join us as a Member on the same day as your visit to and we’ll refund the price of your exhibition ticket. Members receive a range of benefits, including free unlimited entry to paid exhibitions, invitations to Members-only events, access to the Members lounge, and discounts in our shop and café. “...grungy, gritty, and a bit sexy” - Stereogum “...swaggering and devastatingly cool” - NME View times Hot on the heels of announcing their highly anticipated new album Some Like It Hot, the eternally enigmatic UK post-punk darlings bar italia have also unveiled two huge New Zealand shows for this December, brought to you by Strange News Touring and Banished Music. Saturday 13th of December, the band will take the stage at Auckland’s glorious Hollywood Avondale for an all-ages show, playing Meow in Wellington on Sunday 14th December. After bursting onto the scene with two incredible albums in a single year - the brilliant Tracey Denim and the noisy niceness of The Twits - bar italia spent the next while earning a reputation as one of the best live bands in the game, including a sold out and sweaty show at Auckland’s Neck of the Woods. Since then, the band have been plotting their next move in world domination, dropping fan favourite single Cowbella in June, and this week lifting the lid on Some Like It Hot with accompanying tune Fundraiser - with a video featuring Matt “Super Hans” King. The London based band, built around the core of Nina Cristante, Jezmi Tarik Fehmi and Sam Fenton, may have looked to be hiding out this year while cooking up this new batch of tunes, but in reality they’ve been anything but dormant. Cristante teamed up with Yves Tumor for a dangerously good duet on We Don’t Count, while Jezmi and Sam dropped another full-length album under their Double Virgo moniker just last month. With the album dropping on Matador this October, local fans will have a couple of short months to learn the words and get ready to scream and swoon along when bar italia hit our shores this December. Shit yeah! Te wāhi He tīwhiri mō te rohe Every year, The Hollywood hosts a 24-hour movie marathon with a quirky line-up of movies. View times The original ‘wild one’ of rock, IGGY POP along with the Queen of Rock JOAN JETT and THE BLACKHEARTS, and Kiwi favourites, ZED will headline the Summer Concert Tour. Considered by many the ‘Godfather of Punk’ IGGY POP is widely acknowledged as one of THE most dynamic stage performers of all time. He has built a legendary career filled with both critical acclaim and fanatic cult success. This year alone Iggy has performed numerous festival and headline dates across Europe followed by a recent North American tour, he has also just been confirmed for 2026’s Coachella Music Festival. A fearless and legendary rock front man known for his outrageous, unpredictable and physically demanding stage performance, Iggy’s recent set lists have focused on his classic material with songs like ‘T.V. Eye’, ‘Raw Power’, ‘The Passenger’, ‘Lust for Life’ and fan favourite, ‘Real Wild Child’ as well as showcasing songs from his 2023 album ‘Every Loser’. JOAN JETT grew up during a time when Rock ‘n’ Roll was off limits to girls and women, but as a teenager, she promptly blew the door to the boy’s club right off its hinges. After forming her band with the Blackhearts in 1979, she has had eight platinum and gold albums and nine Top 40 singles, including the classics ‘Bad Reputation’, ‘I Love Rock ‘n’ Roll’, ‘I Hate Myself For Loving You’, and ‘Crimson and Clover’. Described as the “Queen of Rock ‘n’ Roll” and “Godmother of Punk”, Joan Jett is celebrated for her rebellious spirit, fierce performances, and raw powerful music. Jett along with her band The Blackhearts will be coming to Aotearoa in 2026. ZED were an essential part of the soundtrack to New Zealand life between 1999 and 2004, amassing an impressive ten Top 40 hits during the height of their career. The band — still performing with their original line-up — has matured into a powerhouse live act. Fans can expect timeless favourites like ‘Renegade Fighter’, ‘Hard to Find Her’, and ‘Glorafilia’, alongside fresh new material that reaffirms their place as one of New Zealand’s most enduring rock bands Te wāhi He tīwhiri mō te rohe Taxis and rideshares can be hard to come by directly after an event. and are delighted to announce the highly-anticipated return of Tony®, EMMY®, and five-time GRAMMY® Award-nominated singer, songwriter, actor, and philanthropist , as he brings the to New Zealand in February 2026. View times Last in New Zealand as part of the 2013 , Groban returns to unanimous anticipation as one of the most outstanding and instantly recognisable voices in music. A natural talent for captivating fans across the globe as both a powerhouse vocalist and dynamic renaissance man, Josh Groban has sold over 35 million albums worldwide, headlined legendary venues on multiple continents and has also entertained audiences with acclaimed film and television appearances. His catalogue spans a series of chart-topping blockbuster albums, including (5x-platinum), (6x-platinum), (7x-platinum), (2x-platinum), (his first UK #1 album), , and his most recent release, . Celebrating an extensively successful career, this May, Groban released , an 18-track career-spanning collection of songs - which he then brought to life on stage during a sold-out, exclusive five-night run at The Colosseum at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas. Most recently he released , a special collection that brings together ten of his fans’ most beloved and rare tracks - many of which have never been available on streaming platforms - along with one brand-new song, “The Constant” - a stunning collaboration written by Josh and the acclaimed songwriting duo Pasek and Paul (The Greatest Showman, La La Land). No stranger to the stage, Groban has packed arenas throughout North America, Europe, Australia, South Africa, New Zealand, and Asia and will now bring these meaningful releases to life once again, across Australia and New Zealand in 2026, performing the most memorable and some never-before-heard tracks live for fans who have been eagerly awaiting his return. Now returning to stages across Australia and New Zealand for the first time in more than 7 years, don’t miss the as Josh Groban brings his unforgettable live show - and that instantly recognisable voice - our way in February and March 2026. View times Now, Tony celebrates a life on stage and screen—sharing stories from his remarkable career, his passion for history, and his thrilling fiction debut , an epic tale of and the bloody birth of England. Hear behind-the-scenes stories from , and beyond – and have the chance to ask Tony anything, from writing his first novel at 78 to why Baldrick still gets the biggest laughs. Drawing on decades of archaeological expertise and his gift for making the past come alive, Tony will reveal the gritty reality behind the legend of in his latest work. What was life really like for ordinary people caught between Saxon kings and Viking raiders? How did political scheming in medieval courts compare to today's power struggles? This isn't just historical fiction – it’s Tony’s unique take on the real events that forged our nation. This will be a night of brilliant storytelling, big laughs, and history with a twist—all delivered by a man who always had… a cunning plan. Laneway Festival is back at Western Springs Stadium View times This summer, the beloved tastemaker festival celebrates its 21st birthday with a refreshed route across six Trans-Tasman cities — with Laneway Festival NZ once again leading the tour. In Aotearoa, Laneway Festival Tāmaki Makaurau will take place on Thursday 5 February at Western Springs, shifting to the day before Waitangi Day for the very first time. That means fans can start their long weekend at Laneway, kicking things off with some of the most exciting new music from around the world before the tour heads across the Tasman to five Australian cities. Laneway Festival co-founders Danny Rogers and Jerome Borazio say, “It’s incredible to be celebrating 21 years of Laneway. What began as a little street party in a Melbourne laneway has grown into a summer ritual across Australia and New Zealand. Auckland has been such an important part of that story, and every year we’re blown away by the response from the artists, fans and community that make Laneway so special — 2026 is about honouring that history while looking to the future.” Te wāhi He tīwhiri mō te rohe Being an outdoor venue, it pays to pack a layer (or two) and check the forecast for signs of wet weather ahead. GIVĒON is bringing DEAR BELOVED, THE TOUR to New Zealand February 2026. View times Givēon has made himself one of music’s brightest stars by bringing vivid color, depth, and soul to songs that capture the intensity of life’s twists and turns. After coming to fame via Drake’s “Chicago Freestyle,” the CA native became a force in his own right. Givēon had a whirlwind 2020 after releasing his Platinum-certified “Like I Want You” (225 million cross-platform streams in the US). He kept the momentum with “Heartbreak Anniversary,” a gauzy ballad that peaked at #16 on the Billboard Hot 100, garnered over 668 million streams, and earned 2X Platinum status. In March 2020, Givēon’s debut EP, Take Time, confirmed his evocative songwriting prowess and would be nominated for Best R&B Album at the 2021 Grammys. His fall When It’s All Said and Done EP further explored the peaks and valleys of love and, when re-packaged with its predecessor in 2021, hit #5 on the Billboard 200. After being nominated for a 2020 NAACP Image Award for Outstanding New Artist, he won BET’s 2021 Best New Artist, and his audience is growing—to the tune of over 1.7 billion streams globally. He even hit #1 on the Hot 100 in March on Justin Bieber’s “Peaches.” That hit helped him win award for Best Pop Song at the 2021 MTV VMA‘s where he was nominated for seven awards including Best New Artist, Best R&B and Best Pop Song. Drake then invited Givēon back into his world, this time for a sizzling verse on Certified Lover Boy’s “In the Bible” with Lil Durk—one of a guaranteed run of thrilling collabs to come. And at his festival debut, Lollapalooza 2021, he found a sea of voices who knew his lyrics. But success has never really been a goal—Givēon just wants to bear his soul. Extraordinary. Fierce. Misunderstood? You decide. This summer, dive into the world of . Bringing together cutting-edge science, indigenous perspectives, and hands-on experiences, this exhibition will show how these ancient fishes have evolved over 450 million years, and the role they play in our ocean ecosystems today. Created by the Australian Museum, this exhibition takes you beneath the surface to discover the diversity, biology, and cultural significance of one of the ocean’s most extraordinary creatures. Blending science, storytelling, and immersive design, it’s a chance to see sharks in a way you never have before. Immerse yourself in a specially designed oceanarium, come face-to-face with striking life-sized models, and get hands-on with interactive experiences that reveal the role sharks play in the health of our oceans, the threats they face today, and what we can do to protect them. is the first solo exhibition in Aotearoa New Zealand of Louise Bourgeois (1911–2010), one of the most intriguing and influential artists of the last century. The exhibition brings together a selection of works from an international private collection, exhibited publicly for the first time. The exhibition spans over six decades of Bourgeois’s career, from early paintings made in 1945 to a fabric work from the final year of her life. Widely celebrated for her psychologically charged and bold sculptural practice, Bourgeois explored themes of memory, family, the body and the subconscious, often drawing from personal experiences. She is best known for her series of large spider sculptures, which have been installed in many major international cities. offers an intimate encounter with Bourgeois’s work, and follows the evolution of her art practice over time. Highlights include paintings and her first series of sculptures, the , from the 1940s and early ‘50s; sculptures from the early 1960s; and significant later works, such as textile-based sculptures and sculptural enclosures. (2002) is a wall-mounted example of her internationally acclaimed series of spider sculptures, which she began in the mid-1990s. Also featured is her extraordinary hanging sculpture, , and late outdoor piece, . is proudly supported by the Contemporary Benefactors of Auckland Art Gallery. View times Long Christmas lunch at Auckland Zoo! Where else in Auckland can you share in a Christmas lunch near 133 species of animals? Gather whānau, friends or colleagues for a long Christmas lunch at Auckland Zoo’s iconic Old Elephant House restaurant this year. Our chefs have taken the stress out of the silly season and have a delectable two-course plated lunch menu, so that you and your guests can relax and unwind over two hours. With a mouth-watering roast leg of lamb*, it’s a guilt-free feast with the Zoo just outside for that long post-lunch walk. We have the little cubs covered too, with a special Christmas menu. In addition to the two-course lunch, prepare to explore and enjoy the glorious tracks throughout the Zoo at your leisure all day long! If that’s not an early (and unique) Christmas treat, we don’t know what is! By booking in now, you’ll also be supporting our important wildlife conservation mahi. So, send the message out to the group chat, gather the crew, and make a day of it. (Hot tip: You may even like to organise a Secret Santa for your table and go all out!). $99 per adult. $41 per child (4-14 years). Zoo entry is included in the Christmas lunch ticket price. Auckland Zoo Members receive 15% off with valid I.D. Pre-booking is required, bookings close 7 days before the event or until sold out. The Robertson Gift: Paths through Modernity celebrates the monumental gift of significant artworks from the collection of New York philanthropists Julian (1932–2022) and Josie Robertson (1943–2010) to the Gallery. View times The Robertson Gift: Paths through Modernity celebrates the monumental gift of significant artworks from the collection of New York philanthropists Julian (1932–2022) and Josie Robertson (1943–2010) to the Gallery. The donation comprises 15 works by influential modern European artists, including Pierre Bonnard, Georges Braque, Paul Cezanne, Salvador Dalí, André Derain, Henri Fantin-Latour, Paul Gauguin, Fernand Léger, Henri Matisse, Piet Mondrian and Pablo Picasso. Beginning with the suggestive nude bodies of the late 19th century and ending with a monumental colour-field painting from the 1960s, The Robertson Gift: Paths through Modernity takes visitors on a journey through the major art movements of the modern era, including Impressionism, Post-Impressionism, Fauvism, Cubism, Surrealism, and post-war abstraction. Featuring 49 paintings, prints, drawings and sculpture, the exhibition also includes visitor favourites from the permanent collection as well as loans and other important recent acquisitions, offering a broad survey of the best of late-19th- and early-to-mid 20th-century international art. Image Credit is: (installation view), Mackelvie Trust Collection, Auckland Art Gallery Toi o Tāmaki, purchased 1991. Photography by David St George. View times What makes the Franklin Road Christmas Lights special? It’s simply, local households decorating their homes for the joy of it. Every fairy light, inflatable reindeer, twinkling star, and quirky Christmas scene is dreamed up and created by the people who live right here. Set in a beguiling bay on the shores of Tāpapakanga Regional Park, is a boutique music & arts festival like no other. A three-day immersive entertainment extravaganza and the greatest costume party in Aotearoa. View times Splore is a beachside celebration where music, art and community gather beneath the pōhutukawa at Tāpapakanga Regional Park. Days drift from beach swims to dance-floor joy, kids darting between artworks, and friends sharing delicious kai under the trees. As evening arrives, stages glow, costumes shimmer and strangers feel like whānau. It’s playful, warm and genuinely welcoming, a place to rest or rave, reflect or be ridiculous. Salt on your skin, music in your chest, stars overhead. Life at its brightest. Alongside the music sits a generous programme of performance, arts, ceremony and wellbeing. You’ll find dancers, circus artists and storytellers moving through the park, while workshops offer movement, meditation and craft. The whenua shapes the festival. Splore works with Ngāti Whanaunga and Ngāti Pāoa to honour Tāpapakanga, uplifting mātauranga Māori and welcoming guests with care and connection. Pōwhiri opens the gathering and the stories of this place guide the experience. Culture sits at the heart of the celebration, held with respect. Splore also leads with sustainability. Its zero-waste approach, thoughtful design and long-term environmental kaupapa are recognised here and overseas. Everyone plays their part, helping protect the land, waters and wildlife that make Tāpapakanga so special. Come with curiosity. Be open. Be part of it. Te wāhi Tāpapakanga Regional Park

2025 Two-Time PGA Tour winner Ryan Fox returns to his home course to host the 4th edition of Mānuka Phuel Chasing the Fox – the most entertaining golf event of the year. View times Chasing the Fox is New Zealand’s premier short-format golf event — where world-class golf meets unforgettable entertainment. Each December at Ryan Fox’s home course, six holes of high-energy Ambrose action transform the game into a festival of sport, music, and spectacle. This year, Fox is bringing a friend from tour to take on a one-of-a-kind field featuring top sporting teams, pro golfers, YouTube stars, and more. Every team competes not just for bragging rights, but for prizemoney to support their chosen charity. The format is simple but thrilling: professional golfers play as pairs, while celebrity teams get the advantage of three players. It’s fast, unpredictable stroke play with no handicaps — lowest score wins. And if it’s tied, the drama builds to a playoff shootout on the final hole. Fans don’t just watch — they’re part of the action. Walk the fairways alongside the players, soak in the atmosphere, and experience every shot up close. It’s golf like you’ve never seen it before. And when play reaches the legendary Party Hole, the energy hits another level — with world-renowned DJ Cyril performing live as the sun sets. From great food and drinks to live entertainment and interactive fan zones, Chasing the Fox is more than a golf event - it’s a sports entertainment festival that captures the excitement of summer in one incredible day. Te wāhi Royal Auckland & Grange Golf Club He tīwhiri mō te rohe Gates open at 1:00 PM, so we recommend arriving early to avoid the Friday afternoon traffic and make the most of your day. Auckland Zoo is offering in-depth tours of Te Wao Nui at 11am every day of the week. An experienced Zoo Guide will take you on an immersive journey from forest to coast where you’ll learn more about New Zealand’s native animals and plants and their importance in Māori culture. Take an immersive journey through the stunning habitats of Te Wao Nui inspiring every visitor to be kaitiaki (guardians) of our unique wildlife and wild places. Discover the rare and fascinating animals such as iconic kiwi and tuatara that are found nowhere else in the world. Learn about our native plant species and the importance of them in Māori culture, and the environment. Te Wao Nui offers both locals and tourists a truly unique experience of New Zealand’s animals, plants and culture all in one location at Auckland Zoo. Encompassing one fifth of the Zoo, is home to over 100 native plant species of Aotearoa and around 60 different animal species. From the wild and rugged high country, picturesque alpines, wetlands and coast to dense night forests featuring our kiwi habitat – it’s truly an unforgettable experience. Te wāhi He tīwhiri mō te rohe Go early to avoid the crowd. Te huarahi ki reira If you’re driving the zoo is just a few minutes' drive from central Auckland. description: Dive into a deep blue world teeming with life in Ngā Huhua: Abundance, an immersive exhibition celebrating the lifeforce of Te Moana-nui-a-Toi, the outer Hauraki Gulf Marine Park, just beyond Auckland’s shores. Meet the surprising and spectacular creatures that call this place home, from tohorā (whales) to honu (turtles), and explore how this ecosystem now faces new threats. Te Moana-nui-a-Toi, an area largely unknown and rarely visited by most Aucklanders, comes alive through storytelling, ocean science, mātauranga Māori, contemporary art, and the voices of tangata whenua (Ngāti Rehua Ngātiwai ki Aotea). The exhibition reveals how both the giants and the smallest creatures play vital roles in maintaining the balance of this thriving marine world. Each year, these species gather in abundance during the seasonal upwelling of food-rich waters, a natural rhythm that has sustained life here for thousands of years. Today, that lifeforce is under pressure from climate change and human activity. Through interactives, compelling stories, and voices grounded in whakapapa, invites you to deepen your connection to the moana and feel inspired to help protect this extraordinary place. This exhibition is presented in partnership with Ngāti Rehua Ngātiwai ki Aotea, the mana whenua (customary guardians) of Aotea Great Barrier Island, whose whakapapa (ancestry) traces back to Toi, and whose people welcomed Kupe into Rangitāwhiri (Tryphena Harbour). Exhibition is FREE with museum entry Photo: R Robinson www.depth.co.nz Te wāhi Te huarahi ki reira The Museum is a short walk from the centre of town and Waitematā station. Tāmaki Herenga Waka means 'the gathering place of many waka', and these new permanent galleries chronicle Auckland's past, capture its present, and look to the future. Paco Peña is internationally acclaimed as the greatest living exponent of flamenco guitar. View times For over five decades, he has transformed the way audiences across the globe experience this most passionate of art forms. To see him perform is to witness flamenco at its purest—alive, uncompromising, and utterly captivating. Rooted in the culture of Andalucía, flamenco blends centuries of song, dance, and rhythm into a powerful expression of human emotion—grief and joy, struggle and celebration, passion and hope. In Peña’s hands, it becomes both profoundly Spanish and universally moving, resonating with audiences whether or not they know its traditions. Each concert begins with Peña’s spellbinding solo guitar and expands into a full flamenco experience with singers, dancers, and musicians, igniting the stage with fire, virtuosity, and soul. More than a performance, is an invitation to feel the heartbeat of Andalucía. Te wāhi He tīwhiri mō te rohe Learn about the colourful history of this iconic venue on an Auckland Town Hall Tour. View times Celebrate Auckland’s birthday on the water at the 186th Auckland Anniversary Day Regatta – the world’s biggest one-day regatta and New Zealand's oldest sporting event. On Monday 26 January 2026 the Waitematā comes alive with action: keelboats and centreboards racing across the harbour, tugboats roaring in their legendary showdown, dragon boats and waka ama sprinting under paddle power, and even radio-controlled yachts duelling in the marina. “Cassandra has delivered a war cry for the wounded wāhine within so many of us, and it is as fierce as it is vulnerable.” — Tarryn Utiger View times Tessa Ensler loves her job. She’s worked her way up from a working-class background to being a top criminal defence barrister at the top of her game: prosecuting, cross-examining and winning in the courtroom with her quick wit and intelligence. She fights to defend those pleading not guilty – including securing freedom for men accused of rape and sexual assault. Innocent until proven guilty is, after all, the bedrock of human rights. An unexpected event forces Tessa to confront the very system she has spent her life believing in and working within. This is a system where the lines of patriarchal power and burden of proof are not set up to accommodate the lived experience of sexual assault survivors. Acclaimed Olivier and Tony award-winning play, Suzie Miller’s Prima Facie, is an unforgettable story and one-woman tour de force. It is an interrogation of the legal system itself. It asks us whether there is room in that system for emotion and experience. Prima Facie was first produced by Griffin Theatre Company in May 2019 at the SBW Stables Theatre, followed by the award-winning 2022 West End premiere at the Harold Pinter Theatre, which then travelled to the Golden Theatre on Broadway in 2023. Directed by Kiwi acting royalty Michael Hurst and performed by Cassandra Woodhouse, NZ Theatre Company is honoured to bring Prima Facie to the stage. This one final Auckland performance continues the call to action that this story is demanding worldwide: “Somewhere. Sometime. Somehow. Something has to change.” “It’s sublime storytelling from a sublime storyteller, shaped by a theatre genius, and it’s for us. A gift without ego. ” — Lexie Matheson Te wāhi Te huarahi ki reira ASB Waterfront Theatre is a 17-minute walk from Waitematā Station and accessible by many bus routes, including the City Link route.

description: Yoga explores the expansiveness of what it is to be human – mind, body, spirit – in a non-competitive practice that allows individuals their own unique inquiry into the fascinating enigma of life. View times These hour-long Hatha yoga classes will include warm-up stretching, building to stronger poses, including flow balance and breath focus. Warming down will lead into breath practice, ending with a brief relaxation or meditation. Our practice and practice space is open to beginners as well as more experienced yogis aged 14 years and over. Penny Hacking completed her advanced Hatha yoga teacher training through Ashram Yoga Auckland. She has completed mental health awareness training, holds a current First Aid Certificate and is a member of the New Zealand Registered Exercise Professionals (REPs) and Yoga New Zealand, the national registration body for yoga teachers. Penny is committed to learning through yoga and working with like-minded individuals to enhance a greater balance of physical, mental and emotional well-being and resilience. Bookings are essential as we are no longer accepting over the counter purchases on the day. Condition of participation: please do not register or attend if you currently have any medical conditions, health issues (including injuries, surgeries) or illnesses that could affect your ability to undertake this class safely. We also offer evening yoga classes on Tuesdays, click to book.
